lead_paragraph: The statistics on deaths, which the government has stopped reporting, offer a rare glimpse into the Mexican military’s role in its fight against cartels.

byline.contributor: Azam Ahmed reported from Mexico City, and Eric Schmitt from Washington. Paulina Villegas contributed reporting from Mexico City.
byline.original: By AZAM AHMED and ERIC SCHMITT

headline.print_headline: Mexican Military Runs Up Body Count in Drug War
headline.main: Mexican Military Runs Up Body Count in Drug War

snippet: The statistics on deaths, which the government has stopped reporting, offer a rare glimpse into the Mexican military’s role in its fight against cartels.
abstract: Experts say Mexican military's kill rate against people suspected of organized crime and drug running is astronomically high, with its armed forces killing eight enemies for every one it wounds; statistics highlight how growing number of soldiers have been forced on front lines in battle against drug cartels, contributing to surge of human rights abuses that Mexican government has done little to stop.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
